column2: Salisbury was the site of a lynching of a black man. Matthew Williams was accused of murdering his white employer
column4: at his office on Lake Street.  The authorities found D.J. Elliot dead at his desk
column6: James Elliot present
column7: and Matthew Williams incapacitated by several gunshot wounds. After being taken to Peninsula General Hospital
column8: a 300-man white mob threw Williams from a second-floor window to the crowd below
column10: tied to a truck and dragged three blocks to the county court house. There they hanged him from a tree
column11: before he had any chance of a trial. The mob paraded Williams' body through the black part of Salisbury for intimidation
column12: and mutilated and burned him. It was the 32nd lynching in Maryland since 1882. No one was prosecuted for Williams' killing
column13: as was typical in lynchings. As of 2007
column14: there was no commemoration of the extrajudicial killing.

column1: Salisbury is a municipality within Wicomico County.  The form of government is strong-mayor
column2: as defined by the City Charter.  In this form
column3: executive functions are vested in a popularly elected mayor who serves a four-year term; currently Jacob R. Day. The Mayor is the chief executive officer and the head of the administrative branch of the city government.  In that role
column4: he is responsible for overseeing the various departments in the city
column5: ensuring that the ordinances of the city are executed
column6: providing an annual report on the financial condition and accomplishments of the city
column7: appointing the heads of all departments and members of committees and commissions
column9: and supervise the City Administrator who manages day-to-day functions.  The City Administrator is the supervisor of all department heads
column10: except the City Clerk and City Attorney. The City Administrator may also perform all other tasks delegated by the Mayor. Legislative and oversight functions are the purview of the elected council. The five council members are elected to four-year terms from the city's five districts. City elections are non-partisan. The council meets in regular session the second and fourth Monday of each month in Council Chambers.  Council work sessions are held the first and third Monday of each month. The council also holds the ability to fill vacancies in the council or appoint an acting mayor when a vacancy occurs.

column1: The Eastern Shore Baseball League was headquartered in Salisbury; two franchises—the Salisbury Cardinals and the Salisbury Indians—called the city home. Today
column2: the Delmarva Shorebirds represent the town in the South Atlantic League. The Eastern Shore Baseball Hall of Fame is housed at the Arthur W. Perdue Stadium. The Shorebirds are a Single-A Affiliate of the Baltimore Orioles.

column1: Salisbury is served by two major highways—U.S. Route 13
column2: one of the major north–south routes of the Delmarva Peninsula
column4: one of the major east–west routes on the peninsula.  US 13 connects Salisbury to Dover
column6: Virginia and is known as the Ocean Highway
column7: while US 50 serves as the main route between the Baltimore/Washington region and many of the major cities on Delmarva
column8: including Ocean City; it is known as the Ocean Gateway.  US 13 and US 50 originally passed through the central business district
column9: but have been subsequently rerouted onto the Salisbury Bypass
column10: a 3/4 beltway around the city that allows through traffic on US 13 and US 50 to bypass the downtown area; earlier routes of both highways are now U.S. Route 13 Business and U.S. Route 50 Business.  Earlier still
column11: US 13 was routed along Division Street and US 50 along Main Street.

column1: The city is also served by Maryland Route 12
column2: a rural highway that connects Salisbury to the town of Snow Hill
column4: a rural highway that connects Salisbury to Nanticoke and Quantico.

column1: The Delmarva Central Railroad provides freight rail service to Salisbury.The city is served by daily scheduled American Eagle service to both Philadelphia
column3: North Carolina at the Wicomico Regional Airport. Additionally
column4: the Port of Salisbury offers respite for recreational boaters and commercial tug boats.  Salisbury's navigable stop on the Wicomico River is the second largest and second busiest commercial port in Maryland.The city is also served by Shore Transit
column5: which provides local bus service throughout the city
column6: and also services points outside the city within the tri-county area
column7: such as Ocean City's public transportation system.  The major transfer point is on Calvert Street
column8: in downtown Salisbury.Greyhound Lines provides intercity bus service to Salisbury from a bus stop at the Shore Transit Tri-County facility. From this stop
column9: direct service is provided to various locations including the Port Authority Bus Terminal in New York City
column12: the Baltimore Greyhound Terminal in Baltimore
column14: Virginia. BayRunner Shuttle offers shuttle service from the Baltimore-Washington International Airport and the BWI Rail Station to Salisbury. Amtrak Thruway Motorcoach service is available via Greyhound Lines to Wilmington and BayRunner Shuttle to the BWI Rail Station.
